div.p: In this note we prove the Weinstein conjecture for a class of symplectic manifolds including the uniruled manifolds based on Liu-Tianâ€™s result.

p.span: The Weinstein conjecture in the uniruled manifolds
Guangcun Lu111Partially supported by the NNSF 19971045 of China.

div.p: [5pt] Nankai Institute of Mathematics, Nankai University
Tianjin 300071, P. R. China
[5pt] (E-mail: gclu@nankai.edu.cn)
[3pt]
Key words : Weinstein conjecture, Gromov-Witten invariants, uniruled manifold.

Since 1978 A. Weinstein proposed his famous conjecture that every hypersurface of contact type in the symplectic manifolds carries a closed characteristic([We]), many results were obtained (cf.[C][FHV][H][HV1][HV2][LiuT][Lu1][Lu2][V1][V2][V3]) after C.Viterbo first proved it in (â„2â¢n,Ï‰0)superscriptâ„2ğ‘›subscriptğœ”0OPEN:( ATOM:symbol-â„ POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\mbox{\Bb R}^{2n},\omega_{0}) in 1986([V1]). Not long ago Gang Liu and Gang Tian established a deep relation between this conjecture and the Gromov-Witten invariants and got several general results as corollaries([LiuT]).

Assume Sğ‘†italic-SS to be a hypersurface of contact type in a closed connected symplectic manifold (V,Ï‰)ğ‘‰ğœ”OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(V,\omega) separating Vğ‘‰italic-VV in the sense of [LiuT], i.e. there exist submanifolds V+subscriptğ‘‰italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{+} and V-subscriptğ‘‰italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{-} with common boundary Sğ‘†italic-SS such that V=V+âˆªV-ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘‰subscriptğ‘‰italic-V RELOP:equals italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:union italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV=V_{+}\cup V_{-} and S=V+âˆ©V-ğ‘†subscriptğ‘‰subscriptğ‘‰italic-S RELOP:equals italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:intersection italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS=V_{+}\cap V_{-}, then the following result holds.

Theorem 1([LiuT])â€ƒIf there exist AâˆˆH2â¢(V;â„¤)ğ´subscriptğ»2ğ‘‰â„¤italic-A RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„¤ CLOSE:)A\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb Z}) and Î±+,Î±-âˆˆHâˆ—â¢(V;â„š)subscriptğ›¼subscriptğ›¼subscriptğ»normal-âˆ—ğ‘‰â„šitalic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„š CLOSE:)\alpha_{+},\,\alpha_{-}\in H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb Q}), such that

p.span: then Sğ‘†italic-SS carries at least one closed characteristic.

div.p: Recall that for a given AâˆˆH2â¢(V;â„¤)ğ´subscriptğ»2ğ‘‰â„¤italic-A RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„¤ CLOSE:)A\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb Z}) the Gromov-Witten invariant of genus gğ‘”italic-gg and with m+2 marked points is a homomorphism

div.p: (see [FO][LiT][R][Si]). Though one so far does not yet know whether the GW invariants defined in the four papers agree or not, we believe that they have the same vanishing or nonvanishing properties, i.e., for any given classes CâˆˆHâˆ—â¢(â„³Â¯g,m+2;â„š)ğ¶subscriptğ»âˆ—subscriptÂ¯â„³ğ‘”ğ‘š2â„šitalic-C RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„š CLOSE:)C\in H_{\ast}(\overline{\cal M}_{g,m+2};\mbox{\Bb Q}) and Î²1,â‹¯,Î²m+2âˆˆHâˆ—â¢(V;â„š)subscriptğ›½1â‹¯subscriptğ›½ğ‘š2subscriptğ»âˆ—ğ‘‰â„šitalic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„š CLOSE:)\beta_{1},\cdots,\beta_{m+2}\in H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb Q}) one of this four versions vanishes on (C;Î²1,â‹¯,Î²m+2)ğ¶subscriptğ›½1â‹¯subscriptğ›½ğ‘š2OPEN:( italic-C PUNCT:; italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(C;\beta_{1},\cdots,\beta_{m+2}) if and only if any other three ones vanish on them. In addition, the version of [R] is actually a homomorphism from Hâˆ—â¢(â„³Â¯g,m+2;â„)Ã—Hâˆ—â¢(V;â„)m+2subscriptğ»âˆ—subscriptÂ¯â„³ğ‘”ğ‘š2â„subscriptğ»âˆ—superscriptğ‘‰â„ğ‘š2italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„ CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„ CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endH_{\ast}(\overline{\cal M}_{g,m+2};\mbox{\Bb R})\times H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb R}% )^{m+2} to â„. However, using the facts that Hâˆ—â¢(M;â„š)subscriptğ»âˆ—ğ‘€â„šitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„š CLOSE:)H_{\ast}(M;\mbox{\Bb Q}) is dense Hâˆ—â¢(M;â„)subscriptğ»âˆ—ğ‘€â„italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„ CLOSE:)H_{\ast}(M;\mbox{\Bb R}) for M=V,â„³Â¯g,kğ‘€ğ‘‰subscriptÂ¯â„³ğ‘”ğ‘˜italic-M RELOP:equals italic-V PUNCT:, OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM=V,\overline{\cal M}_{g,k} and Î¨A,g,m+2subscriptÎ¨ğ´ğ‘”ğ‘š2Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Psi_{A,g,m+2} is always a homomorphism one can naturally extend the other three versions to the homomorphisms from Hâˆ—â¢(â„³Â¯g,m+2;â„)Ã—Hâˆ—â¢(V;â„)m+2subscriptğ»âˆ—subscriptÂ¯â„³ğ‘”ğ‘š2â„subscriptğ»âˆ—superscriptğ‘‰â„ğ‘š2italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„ CLOSE:) MULOP:times italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„ CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endH_{\ast}(\overline{\cal M}_{g,m+2};\mbox{\Bb R})\times H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb R}% )^{m+2} to â„. Below we always mean the extended versions when they can not clearly explained in the original versions. Our main result is

Theorem 2â€ƒFor a connected closed symplectic manifold (V,Ï‰)ğ‘‰ğœ”OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(V,\omega), if there exist AâˆˆH2â¢(V;â„¤)ğ´subscriptğ»2ğ‘‰â„¤italic-A RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„¤ CLOSE:)A\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb Z}), CâˆˆHâˆ—â¢(MÂ¯g,m+2;â„š)ğ¶subscriptğ»normal-âˆ—subscriptnormal-Â¯normal-Mğ‘”ğ‘š2â„šitalic-C RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start caligraphic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„š CLOSE:)C\in H_{\ast}(\overline{\cal M}_{g,m+2};\mbox{\Bb Q}) and Î²1,â‹¯,Î²m+1âˆˆHâˆ—â¢(V;â„š)subscriptğ›½1normal-â‹¯subscriptğ›½ğ‘š1subscriptğ»normal-âˆ—ğ‘‰â„šitalic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„š CLOSE:)\beta_{1},\cdots,\beta_{m+1}\in H_{\ast}(V;\mbox{\Bb Q}) such that

p.span: for (g,m)â‰ (0,0)ğ‘”ğ‘š00OPEN:( italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)(g,m)\neq(0,0) and the single point class [pâ¢t]delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘¡OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:][pt], then every hypersurface of contact type Sğ‘†italic-SS in the symplectic manifold Vğ‘‰italic-VV separating Vğ‘‰italic-VV carries a closed characteristic. Specially, if g=0ğ‘”0italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:0g=0 we can also guarantee that Sğ‘†italic-SS carries one contractible ( in Vğ‘‰italic-VV) closed characteristic.

div.p: In case g=0ğ‘”0italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:0g=0 it is not difficult to prove that Proposition 2.5(5) and Proposition 2.6 in [RT] still hold for any closed symplectic manifold (V,Ï‰)ğ‘‰ğœ”OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(V,\omega) with the method of [R]. That is,

for the product manifold (V,Ï‰)=(V1Ã—V2,Ï‰1âŠ•Ï‰2)ğ‘‰ğœ”subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2direct-sumsubscriptğœ”1subscriptğœ”2OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:direct-sum italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(V,\omega)=(V_{1}\times V_{2},\omega_{1}\oplus\omega_{2}) of any two closed symplectic manifolds (V1,Ï‰1)subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğœ”1OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(V_{1},\omega_{1}) and (V2,Ï‰2)subscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğœ”2OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(V_{2},\omega_{2}) it holds that

div.p: Thus if Î¨A2,0,m+1V2â¢([pâ¢t];[pâ¢t],Î²1,â‹¯,Î²m)â‰ 0subscriptsuperscriptÎ¨subscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğ´20ğ‘š1delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½1â‹¯subscriptğ›½ğ‘š0Psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0\Psi^{V_{2}}_{A_{2},0,m+1}([pt];[pt],\beta_{1},\cdots,\beta_{m})\neq 0 we get

div.p: for A1=0subscriptğ´10italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0A_{1}=0 and Î±1=â‹¯=Î±m=[V1]subscriptğ›¼1â‹¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘šdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‰1italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ID:cdots RELOP:equals italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:[ italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]\alpha_{1}=\cdots=\alpha_{m}=[V_{1}]. This leads to

Corollary 3â€ƒWeinstein conjecture holds in the product symplectic manifolds of any closed symplectic manifold and a symplectic manifold satisfying the condition of Theorem 2 for g=0ğ‘”0italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:0g=0.

Recall that a smooth Kahler manifold (M,Ï‰)ğ‘€ğœ”OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(M,\omega) is called uniruled if it can be covered by rational curves. Y. Miyaoka and S. Mori showed that a smooth complex projective manifold Xğ‘‹italic-XX is uniruled if and only if there exists a non-empty open subset UâŠ‚Xğ‘ˆğ‘‹italic-U RELOP:subset-of italic-XU\subset X such that for every xâˆˆUğ‘¥ğ‘ˆitalic-x RELOP:element-of italic-Ux\in U there is an irreducible curve Cğ¶italic-CC with (KX,C)<0subscriptğ¾ğ‘‹ğ¶0OPEN:( italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-C CLOSE:) RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0(K_{X},C)<0 through xğ‘¥italic-xx([MiMo]). Specially, any Fano manifold is uniruled([Ko]). The complex projective spaces, the complete intersections in it, the Grassmann manifolds and more general flag manifold are the important examples of the Fano manifolds. In [R, Prop. 4.9] it was proved that if a smooth Kahler manifold Mğ‘€italic-MM is symplectic deformation equivalient to uniruled manifold, Mğ‘€italic-MM is uniruled. Actually, as mentioned there, Kollar showed that on the uniruled manifold (M,Ï‰)ğ‘€ğœ”OPEN:( italic-M PUNCT:, italic-omega CLOSE:)(M,\omega) there exists a class AâˆˆH2â¢(V;â„¤)ğ´subscriptğ»2ğ‘‰â„¤italic-A RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„¤ CLOSE:)A\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb Z}) such that

semantics.annotation: Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0

div.p: for some classes Î²1subscriptğ›½1italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{1} and Î²2subscriptğ›½2italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{2}(see [R] for more general case). Combing these with Corollary 3 we get

Corollary 4â€ƒEvery hypersurface Sğ‘†italic-SS of contact type in the uniruled manifold Vğ‘‰italic-VV or the product of any closed symplectic manifold and an uniruled manifold carries one contractible ( in Vğ‘‰italic-VV) closed characteristic.
The ideas of proof are combing Liu-Tianâ€™s Theorem 1 above, the properties of the Gromov-Witten invariants and Viterbroâ€™s trick of [V4].
Proof of Theorem 2â€ƒUnder the assumptions of Theorem 2, the reduction formula of the Gromov-Witten invariants([R, Prop. C]) implies that

div.p: since Ağ´italic-AA contains the nontrivial pseudoholomorphic curves. To use Theorem 1 we need to show that there exists a homology class Î³âˆˆH2â¢(V;â„)ğ›¾subscriptğ»2ğ‘‰â„italic-gamma RELOP:element-of italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:; ATOM:symbol-â„ CLOSE:)\gamma\in H_{2}(V;\mbox{\Bb R}) with support sâ¢uâ¢pâ¢pâ¢(Î³)â†ªiâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V+)â†ªğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰italic-s italic-u italic-p italic-p OPEN:( italic-gamma CLOSE:) ARROW:hookrightarrow italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)supp(\gamma)\hookrightarrow int(V_{+})( or iâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V-)ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)int(V_{-})) such that

div.p: To this goal we note Sğ‘†italic-SS to be a hypersurface of contact type, and thus there exists a Liouville vector field Xğ‘‹italic-XX defined in a neighborhood Uğ‘ˆitalic-UU of Sğ‘†italic-SS, which is transverse to Sğ‘†italic-SS. The flow of Xğ‘‹italic-XX define a diffeomorphism Î¦Î¦Phi\Phi from SÃ—(-3â¢Ïµ,3â¢Ïµ)ğ‘†3italic-Ïµ3italic-Ïµitalic-S MULOP:times OPEN:( ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 italic-epsilon PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 italic-epsilon CLOSE:)S\times(-3\epsilon,3\epsilon) onto an open neighborhood of Sğ‘†italic-SS in Uğ‘ˆitalic-UU for some Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0\epsilon>0. Define Î²:=fâ¢Î±assignğ›½ğ‘“ğ›¼italic-beta RELOP:assign italic-f italic-alpha\beta:=f\alpha. Now from the naturality of Poincare-Lefschetz duality ([p.296, Sp]): H2â¢n-2â¢(V-UÏµ)â‰…H2â¢(V,UÏµ)subscriptğ»2ğ‘›2ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ»2ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals italic-H POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)H_{2n-2}(V-U_{\epsilon})\cong H^{2}(V,U_{\epsilon}) it follows that we can choose a cycle representive Î³^^ğ›¾OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end\widehat{\gamma} of Î³:=Pâ¢Dâ¢([Ï‰])assignğ›¾ğ‘ƒğ·delimited-[]ğœ”italic-gamma RELOP:assign italic-P italic-D OPEN:( OPEN:[ italic-omega CLOSE:] CLOSE:)\gamma:=PD([\omega]) with support sâ¢uâ¢pâ¢pâ¢(Î³^)â†ªiâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V-UÏµ)â†ªğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘^ğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµitalic-s italic-u italic-p italic-p OPEN:( OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end CLOSE:) ARROW:hookrightarrow italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)supp(\widehat{\gamma})\hookrightarrow int(V-U_{\epsilon}). Notice that V-UÏµâŠ‚V-S=iâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V+)âˆªiâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V-)ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµğ‘‰ğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:subset-of italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-S RELOP:equals italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:union italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)V-U_{\epsilon}\subset V-S=int(V_{+})\cup int(V_{-}) and iâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V+)âˆ©iâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V-)=âˆ…ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:intersection italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ID:empty-setint(V_{+})\cap int(V_{-})=\emptyset. We can denote by Î³^+subscript^ğ›¾OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\widehat{\gamma}_{+} and Î³^-subscript^ğ›¾OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\widehat{\gamma}_{-} the union of connected components of Î³^^ğ›¾OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end\widehat{\gamma} lying iâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V+)ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)int(V_{+}) and iâ¢nâ¢tâ¢(V-)ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰italic-i italic-n italic-t OPEN:( italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)int(V_{-}) respectively. Then the homology classes determined by them in Hâˆ—â¢(V,â„)subscriptğ»âˆ—ğ‘‰â„italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-V PUNCT:, ATOM:symbol-â„ CLOSE:)H_{\ast}(V,\mbox{\Bb R}) satisfy: [Î³^+]+[Î³^-]=Î³delimited-[]subscript^ğ›¾delimited-[]subscript^ğ›¾ğ›¾OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] ADDOP:plus OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] RELOP:equals italic-gamma[\widehat{\gamma}_{+}]+[\widehat{\gamma}_{-}]=\gamma. Thus [Î³^+]delimited-[]subscript^ğ›¾OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:][\widehat{\gamma}_{+}] and [Î³^-]delimited-[]subscript^ğ›¾OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:][\widehat{\gamma}_{-}] have at least one nonzero class. By the property of the Gromov-Witten invariants we get

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-gamma PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.

div.p: Hence the right side of (4) has at least one nonzero term. Without loss of generality we assume that

semantics.annotation: Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A PUNCT:, italic-g PUNCT:, italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-C CLOSE:) PUNCT:; OPEN:[ italic-p italic-t CLOSE:] PUNCT:, OPEN:[ OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.

div.p: Then Theorem 1 directly leads to the first conclusion.
The second claim is easily obtained by carefully checking the arguments in [LiuT]. â–¡â–¡Box\Box

Remark 5Â Â Actually we believe that Theorem 1 still holds provided the hypersurface Sğ‘†italic-SS of contact type therein is replaced by the stable hypersurface in the sense of [HV2]. Hence the hypersurface Sğ‘†italic-SS of contact type in our results above may be replaced by the stable hypersurface for which the symplectic form is exact in some open neighborhood of it.

Remark 6Â Â In [B] it was proved that the system of Gromov-Witten invariants of the product of two varieties is equal to the tensor product of the systems of Gromov-Witten invariants of the two factors. Using the methods developed in [FO][LiT][R][Si] we believe that one can still prove these product formula of Gromov-Witten invariants with any genus for any product of two closed symplectic manifolds, and thus Corollary 3 also holds for any genus gğ‘”italic-gg.

AcknowledgementsÂ Â I would like to express my hearty thanks to Professor Claude Viterbo for his many valuable discussions and sending his recent preprint [V4] to me. I wish to acknowledge Professor Janos Kollar for his telling me some properties on the uniruled manifolds. He also thanks the referee for his good suggestions to improve the original version.
